<@U01DZUA88S1> wrote the below back in last year, and unfortunately, I did not act on it in time, and then forgot .. but somehow it suddenly appeared from the Slack history despite its age, so I'm reposting that ~we~I don't forget again:

> Hi <@U027JEHGZRA>, we were looking at <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/pull/41> at the R Dev Day @ LatinR and we have a couple of issues:
> • We couldn't work out how to suggest a new term, i.e. how to get to the dialog shown in this <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/blob/43bf073e29c349705a844bf8fd3fb385f69c1100/web/img/example_form.png|screenshot> cc <@U07BR2DAFNK>
>     ◦ Update: it seems that I can get to this dialog by going to <https://translate.rx.studio/projects/r-project/glossary/en_GB/> and clicking the "Add new glossary term", but probably this is because I am an en_gb lead? Ideally anyone should be able to suggest a new term (for the terminology list or for a specific language).
> • It would be good to add the translation team leads (as defined here: <https://translate.rx.studio/projects/r-project/#information>) to the set of users with permissions to:
>     ◦  Approve suggested translations for existing glossary terms
>     ◦ Approve new terms to their language-specific glossary or the terminology list.
> 
> Teams can then discuss here if they want to change the group of leaders for their language (e.g. if a team lead becomes inactive). (edited) 
> 
> <@U027JEHGZRA>, please make sure the team leads also have the two permissions I mention in the last bullet point here - these are more important than adding terms to the English glossary, since at the moment it is preventing teams from hitting 100% translation!
I'm also marking my calendar on March 21 for the R Contribution Working Group to discuss this in more details, as after a look, translator team leads should have permissions to manage their glossary.
To solve for the request so that they can also manage the global glossary, we will need to create a new team anyway due to technical limitations in the permission systems (as far as I understand),
as team leads can only have permissions to their own languages.
